AFAIK, Hardware backdoors are actually in software which might not even visible / reachable by user. Like any software, these can have bugs, and backdoors.

If such a backdoor exists, than it would make every encryption pointless, as it can see what you type in your keyboard, or virtual keyboard in case of mobile phones.

but correct me if I'm wrong.

and I have an idea to solve it:

[offline device] <==> [online device] <---> connection <----> [online device] <==> [offline device]
- offline devices can never reach internet
- pub/priv keys are generated on the offline devices, getting entropy from the environment (sensors, whatever)
- the connection between the online - offline device ( == ) 
  - when you want to send a message, you type it in a keyboard in the offline device, it does the encoding, and send it to the online device, encrypted, via a simulated USB keyboard.
  - when you want to see an encrypted message, the offline message recognizes the encrypted text via a camera, decrypts, and displays it to you.

I know it sounds complicated, but this is the only way I can think of, which avoids risks of working with "backdoored" devices. Let me know what you think :)
